Eliz. cap. 2 together with the tryal of Alexander Lumsden, a Scotchman, and the arraignment of David Joseph Kemish for the same offence : at the sessions of Oyer and Terminer in the Old-Baily, on Saturday, January 17th, 1679.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRYALS AND CONDEMNATION OF LIONEL ANDERSON, alias Munſon, WILLIAM RUSSEL, alias Napper, CHARLES PARRIS, alias Parry, HENRY STARKEY, JAMES CORKER, And WILLIAM MARSHAL, FOR HIGH TREASON, AS Romiſh Prieſts, Upon the Statute of 27. Eliz. Cap. 2. Together with the Tryal of ALEXANDER LUMSDEN a Scotchman, AND The Arraignment of DAVID JOSEPH KEMISH for the ſame Offence. At the Seſſions of Oyer and Terminer in the Old-Baily, on Saturday January 17th. 1679.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Collins and John Starkey Book-Sellers in Fleet-Street near Temple-Bar, 1680.

div.head: THE TRYALS, &c.
div.opener: On Saturday the 17th of January, 1679. at the Seſſions-Houſe in the Old-Bayley, by Vertue of His Majeſties Commiſſion of Oyer and Terminer and Goal-delivery of Newgate, for the County of Middleſex and City of London, the Perſons hereafter named were Arraigned and Tryed. And after the uſual Proclamation for Attendance was made, the Court proceeded in this manner:

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Crown.
sp.p: KEeper, ſet David Joſeph Kemiſh to the Bar, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: David Joſeph Kemiſh,
sp.p: Hold up thy Hand, (which he did.)

Thou ſtandeſt Indicted by the Name of David Joſeph Kemiſh of the Pariſh of St. Giles's in the Fields, in the County of Middleſex, Clerk, for that thou being born within the Dominions of our Soveraign Lord the King, and being a Prieſt, made and ordained by authority derived from the See of Rome, after the Feaſt of the Nativity of St. John Baptiſt, in the firſt Year of the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and before the 15th of November, in the thirtieth year of the Reign of our Soveraign Lord the King that now is, the Laws and Statutes of this Kingdom of England not regarding, nor the Penalties in the ſame contained any ways fearing, the ſaid 15th day of November, in the thirtieth year of the King aforeſaid, at the Pariſh of St. Giles's in the Fields, in the County of Middleſex aforeſaid, traiterouſly, and as a falſe Traytor of our Soveraign Lord the King, thou waſt and didſt remain and abide againſt the Form of the Statute in this Caſe made and provided, and againſt the Peace of our Soveraign Lord the King his Crown and Dignity. How ſayeſt thou, David Joſeph Kemiſh, Art thou Guilty of this High Treaſon whereof thou ſtandeſt Indicted, or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Kemiſh.
sp.p: Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Culprit, How wilt thou be Tryed?

sp.speaker: Kemiſh.
sp.p: By God and my Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: God ſend thee a good deliverance.

sp.speaker: Kemiſh.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak, I am not able to ſtand upon my Legs a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What does he ſay?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: He ſays he is ſo ill and weak he is not able to ſtand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then he muſt have a Stool.

sp.speaker: Kemiſh.
sp.p: I am not able to ſpeak in my own defence, and I have had no time to prepare my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Captain, He ſhall ſpeak ſoftly to you; and you ſhall report it to the Court again.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: You may ſpeak ſoftly to me, and I will give an account what you ſay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How will he be Tryed? ask him.

sp.speaker: Kemiſh.
sp.p: I would deſire my Tryal might be deferr'd till I be in a condition to Anſwer for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis, I think, very fit, if your Lordſhips pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: He muſt Plead firſt. Have you recorded his Plea?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis recorded.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why then look you Captain Richardſon, you muſt take him back, the Court does think fit, and Mr. Attorney does think fit, by reaſon of his extraordinary • nfirmity, that it is not ſeaſonable to Try him now. And that the World may not ſay we are grown Barbarous and Inhumane, we are all contented he ſhould be ſet by. Therefore let him be returned back, and in the mean time you muſt take care that he have that reaſonable looking to as is fit for a man in his condition to have.

sp.speaker: L. C. Baron.
sp.p: Acquaint him with what the Court ſays to you.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: I will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: M. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire that the Judges may declare their Opinion in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They have done ſo already, we do all conſent to it. Therefore take him, and go get him a bed.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set William Ruſſel, alias Napper, to the Bar. Who was Arraigned upon an Indictment of the ſame form, only the day of the Fact differing, which was laid to be the 27th of November, in 30 Car. 2. To which he likewiſe pleaded, Not Guilty, and put himſelf upon the Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set Henry Starkey to the Bar. Whoſe Indictment was the ſame, only the Time differing, which was the 26th of January, 30 Car. 2. And he alſo pleaded, Not Guilty, and put himſelf upon the Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Cr.
sp.p: Set William Marſhal to the Bar. Who being Arraigned upon a like Indictment, and the time mentioned to be the 15th of January, 30 Car. 2. And being asked, Whether Guilty, or not Guilty, anſwered thus:

sp.speaker: Marſhal.
sp.p: My Lord, I do find by this Indictment, that I am Arraigned for the ſame Crime for which I was tryed before: I do humbly deſire to know, Whether, according to Law, I can be tryed twice for the ſame Fact?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: No, according to the Law you cannot be tryed twice for the ſame Fact, nor are you; for before you were Indicted for having an hand in the great Conſpiracy, for being a Conſpirator in the Plot, and now you are Tryed for being a Prieſt, and abiding in England.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I was tryed before your Lordſhip as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: You were ſo.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Now I am tryed for a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Which is another Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: If I am tryed for a Prieſt, I conceive I cannot be tryed unleſs as a Criminal Prieſt: and I conceive I cannot be tryed as a Criminal Prieſt, unleſs it be as a Prieſt that hath had ſome attempt or deſign againſt the Government.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Nay, you miſtake there; There may be Prieſts that have had no hand in the Plot; if you were acquitted for the Plot, yet you remain a Prieſt ſtill. Do you ſuppoſe then that every Prieſt had a hand in the Plot?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly conceive, that Prieſthood as Prieſthood is no Crime at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: That is no Crime at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Come, You muſt plead without more a do: and you muſt not uſe any more Speeches.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: You muſt be governed in all things by the direction of the Court.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I do ſubmit to the direction of this Honourable Bench; but, my Lord, give me leave to ſay, I ſuppoſe I am indicted upon 27. Eliz. Now if it be made appear, that according to that Statute Prieſthood alone is not Treaſon—

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Then you muſt ſpeak it afterwards, but now you muſt plead.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But if it be at leaſt made doubtful, then it becomes a matter of Law, and I have juſt occaſion to inſiſt upon it, and pray Counſel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt Dolben.
sp.p: You muſt plead to the Indictment firſt.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Why can I ask Counſel after Plea pleaded?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Yes, you may if matter of Law ariſe: and you may have Counſel as to that matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: The Court is of Counſel for you in ſuch a caſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Baron.
sp.p: But you muſt plead firſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You cannot be heard at all till you have pleaded to the Indictment.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray take the directions of the Court.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I have a great deal of reaſon to ſubmit to this Honourable Court, that hath been ſo full of Mercy and Clemency, and therefore I do anſwer, That I am not guilty.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: How wilt thou be tryed?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: By the King and my Countrey.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, that will not do.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: By God and my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: God ſend thee good deliverance. Set Alexander Lumsden to the Bar. Whoſe Indictment being of the ſame nature, only reciting the Fact to be 11. Maii 31. Car. 2di. he pleaded, Not Guilty, and put himſelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set James Corker to the Bar; who was alſo Arraigned for the ſame Treaſon done upon the 24. Octobr. 30. Car. 2di. and being asked, whether Guilty or not Guilty, anſwered in theſe words.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly beg the Judgment of the Court; I humbly conceive, my Lord, I have been already tryed and acquitted for this Crime.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, that hath been over-ruled already in the caſe of Marſhall juſt now, who is in the ſame Condition; You are not now tryed for the ſame fact for which you were tryed before.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſuppoſe there is ſomething particular in my caſe: I was expreſly indicted as Clerk, one that received Orders from the See of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: His Addition was Clerk, that is all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you were not charged in that Indictment for this Fact.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, I pleaded to that Indictment, under that Qualification of Clerk.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So men do when they ſay in the Indictment, Labourer, plead to it in that qualification, but if a man plead by the name of Gent. the Queſtion is not whether he be a Gent. or no, but whether he be Guilty of the Fact he is indicted for; and the Queſtion in your caſe was not whether you were Clerk or were not Clerk, but whether you had a hand in the Plot or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: If the Jury had found you a Prieſt at that time, it had been a void finding more than they were to inquire of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: He was told ſo at that time he was not tryed for a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Ellis.
sp.p: After you have Pleaded, then you may urge what you have to ſay.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Then I ſay, I am not Guilty. And he put himſelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Lionel Anderſon, alias Munſon to the Bar. Whoſe Indictment was for being a Prieſt, and abiding here the 28 Jan. 30 Car. 2. And he pleaded not Guilty, and put himſelf upon his Country.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set Charles Parris alias Parry to the Bar, whoſe Indictment was of the ſame Nature, for abiding here 30 Maij. 31 Car. 2. And he alſo pleaded Not Guilty, and put himſelf upon the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Set all the Priſoners to the Bar that are to be Tryed. William Ruſſel, Henry Starkey, William Marſhall, Alexander Lumsden, James Corker, Lionel Anderſon, and Charles Parry.

sp.speaker: Captain Richardſon.
sp.p: They are all on.

sp.speaker: Ruſſel.
sp.p: My Lord, I have been Confined, I have not had my Liberty till within theſe two or three days.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Ruſſel.
sp.p: I have not had my Friends to come to me, to adviſe me upon what account I was to be Tryed.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: He ſays, he wanted his Friends to adviſe for what he was to be Tryed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, he knows he is to be Tryed for a Popiſh Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: Here is one ſays he is ſick.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: 'Tis Anderſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: Then he muſt have a Chair to ſit down on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Wee'l Try him firſt that is ſick.

div.p: Then the Priſoners were called to their Challenges, and the Jury of Middleſex appearing upon their Summons, and none of them being excepted againſt, the Twelve that were firſt called and Sworn, were the Gentlemen after named.
Then they were numbred, and Proclamation for Information in uſual manner was made.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, begin with the Sick-man Anderſon; and ſet away the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Lionel Anderſon, hold up thy hand. You that are Sworn look upon the Priſoner, and hearken to his Cauſe. He ſtands Indicted by the name of Lionel Anderſon, &c. Upon this Indictment he hath been Arraigned, and thereunto hath pleaded, Not Guilty; and for his Tryal hath put himſelf upon God and his Countrey, which Country you are. Your Charge is to enquire, whether he be Guilty, &c.

div.p: Then Roger Belwood Eſq; of Council for the King in this Cauſe, opened the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury. The Priſoner at the Bar, Lionel Anderſon, alias Munſon, ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon, and it is alledged in the Indictment, That he being born within the Kings Dominions, and made a Prieſt, and having received Orders by pretended Authority, from the See of Rome, he did the 28th. day of January
laſt come into the Kingdom of England, that is, as 'tis laid, in the Pariſh of St. Giles in the Fields in this County; and there he did abide contrary to the Form of the Statute. And this is laid to be Traiterouſly done. To this he hath pleaded Not Guilty, and we are to prove it upon him by the Kings Evidence, whom we are now to call.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, for my ſtaying in the Kingdom, I had the Kings expreſs Command, and an Order from the Council-Board in the year 71.) They Ordered Mr. Peter Welſh, and my ſelf, and ſome more to ſtay, for Writing againſt the Temporal Power of the Pope, for the Power of the King of England againſt the Court of Rome. After this Plot was Diſcovered, I came to the King, being afraid of being involved in the general Calamity. So I came to the King, and ſaid, Sir, I deſire to know what I may do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do, Why?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Good my Lord hear me out. My Lord Privy Seal brought me an Order from the Council Board, and ſo 'tis Recorded, and I think Dr. Oates will be ſo juſt to me, as to acknowledge that he hath ſeen it, and this is all that I have to ſay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you have an Order from the Council to protect you, you muſt apply your ſelf elſewhere; our buſineſs is to try the ſingle iſſue, whether you have offended againſt the Law.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I that am but a poor ſingle Individuum, who am born with an innate and implicit Obedience to my King, judge whether it lies in my power to diſpute with him and his Council, whether they can do this or no, or that I muſt obey the Kings Command.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: This is not a time for him now to inſiſt on this matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Reſerve your ſelf till the Kings Counſel have done, and the Evidence given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: Let him ſave his Speech till ſuch time as he comes to anſwer for himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Give him a Chair, if he be not able to ſtand.

div.p: Then Sir John Keiling, one of the Kings Learned Counſel in the Law, purſued the Charge thus,

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordſhip and you Gentlemen of the Jury, Lionel Anderſon otherwiſe Munſon the Priſoner at the Bar, ſtands indicted here, for that he being a Subject Born within the Dominions of the King, hath taken Orders from the See of Rome, and hath contrary to the Law come into England, and ſtayed here as a Traytor; for this Treaſon he is indicted, and the Indictment is grounded upon the Statute of the 27th. Eliz. a Statute made almoſt a hundred years ſince, and it was upon great occaſion; for it tells you plainly, That theſe Prieſts that had taken Orders from the See of Rome, were not only buſie in ſeducing and perverting the Kings Subjects to the Romiſh Superſtition, but they had made many attempts upon the Government, raiſing Sedition and, Rebellion and levying of War againſt their Soveraign,
which is evident from the Preamble of the Statute it ſelf. And it is true, the lenity and mildneſs of our Princes hath in a great meaſure let this Statute lye aſleep: they have not been willing to execute the ſeverity of the Law upon all occaſions at all times; but the occaſion being renewed at this time, for the remedying of which, this Statute was principally made, (that is to ſay, raiſing Seditions, and Commotions, and Rebellion againſt the King, the particulars of which I ſhall not inlarge upon it hath been notorious in this place) that is the reaſon of the preſent proſecution of theſe Perſons. Who have not been contented to enjoy the indulgence of our Princes, (which hath been extended to them, notwithſtanding all their former numerous affronts that they have given) but have rais'd new Commotions, and made attempts upon the Perſon of our King, and of our Government, and that is the occaſion upon which theſe Perſons come to be Tryed. It is not purely (tho' that is a main ingredient) that they are tryed quatenus Prieſts, but as Ordained by the See of Rome, and coming into England and abiding here. For a Prieſt, if he be Ordained by the See of Rome, if he comes not here, can do no hurt; but it is his coming and abiding here, that makes him the Subject of this Puniſhment, and hath occaſioned this mans Proſecution. Now my Lord, we ſhall prove that this Anderſon alias Munſon hath taken Orders from the See of Rome, whoſe authority conſtituted him a Prieſt, and this we ſhall prove by ſeveral inſtances and ſteps; and then we doubt not but you will take that care for the preſervation of the Government, and for the Peace and Quiet of the Nation, which becomes you, and give a Verdict according as your Evidence ſhall lead you.

div.p: Then Sir George Strode, the Kings Serjeant at Law, managed the Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Strode.
sp.p: My Lord, we ſhall call our Evidence. The Fact is this, That this Perſon being a Subject of the Kings, and having received Orders from the See of Rome, that is, being a Romiſh Prieſt, did come and abide here contrary to the Statute; not that his Prieſthood is the Crime, no tis his being a Subject of the Kings, and owning an Authority from abroad, and thereby denying the Authority of his own Soveraign. To prove this, we ſhall call Dr. Oates, Mr. Bedlow, Mr. Dangerfield, and Mr. Prance, (who were all Sworn.) Set up Mr. Dangerfield firſt. Mr. Dangerfield, tell my Lord and the Jury what you know of the Priſoner at the Bar, Mr. Anderſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: What I do know againſt him?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, for being a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: What, that particularly?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, that particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p:
My Lord, about the latter end of May, or beginning of June, when I was a Priſoner for Debt in the Kings-Bench, this perſon took occaſion to ſpeak privately to me, and deſired me to go into his Room: he told me he had received a Letter from my Lady Powis, and that Letter was burnt. But the next Letter that
came from my Lady Powis, he would ſhew it me. And he did ſo; and the Contents of the Letter was, as near as I can remember, juſt thus: Sir, You muſt deſire Willoughby to ſcour his Kettle; which was, to Confeſs and receive the Sacrament, to be true to the Cauſe. A little after, that was Saturday, and I think it was the next day, being Sunday, I went into Mr. Anderſons, aliàs Munſon's Chamber, and there I went to Confeſſion, and received Abſolution. And he ſent me to another perſon to receive the Sacrament, who was ſaying Maſs at that time. And when I had received the Sacrament and returned to him again, he did tell me, That he, as a Prieſt, did give me free toleration to go and be drunk, and drink with one Stroude; and I asked him, being ſomething ſcrupulous in the matter, Whether I might lawfully do it, having but juſt received the Sacrament? he told me, Yes, he gave me authority ſo to do, being for the good of the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you a Papiſt then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: You went to Confeſſion to him, and received Abſolution?

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: What was the good of the Cauſe that he meant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, give an account of the whole thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: That was, as I was employed in a general Affair for the Catholicks: for I was to uſe my endeavour to bring over Stroud to be a Witneſs for the Lords in the Tower, concerning the Plot, and to invalidate Mr. Bedloe's Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Here I am upon my Life and Death; all the World knows me, that hath heard of my Name—

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray make no Speeches, if you will ask any Queſtions you may.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: No, I wont. I wiſh that all the Puniſhment of Hell and Damnation may come upon me, if I ever opened my mouth to this Rogue for one Farthing, or about any buſineſs in the World.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt not call him Rogue in open Court. Let us have that reſpect ſhewn us that is fitting, and ſo ſhall you have, but this Language we muſt not ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: In the firſt place, I will bring all the Priſoners in the Kings-Bench Priſon to teſtifie, That I deſired to be removed to Newgate, for here was the greateſt Rogue come in that was in England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: This muſt not be ſuffered.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you will ask him any Queſtions, you may.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Well, come Mr. Dangerfield, in the firſt place, Who ever ſaw you with me? 'Tis impoſſible but ſome body muſt ſee you with me, if we were together, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: My Lord, there is one Hill, that is now a Priſoner in the Kings-Bench, that ſaw me ſeveral times go into his Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there any body by when you confeſs'd your ſelf to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Confeſſions uſe to be in ſecret.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he was not in the Chamber, neither was it reaſonable he ſhould, but he ſaw me go in often.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Surely, Mr. Dangerfield, you and I could not be ſo well acquainted, but ſomebody or other muſt take notice, that we ſpoke together ſometimes. Now if you can produce any one body that will teſtifie it, I will be bound to be hang'd, and ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: He is not bound to bring Witneſſes to this purpoſe. He ſwears the Fact charged upon you poſitively.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dangerfield.
sp.p: This Hill, my Lord, that is in the Kings-Bench, hath made Oath of it before Mr. Juſtice Foſter.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: But, my Lord, this one thing I have to ſay againſt this man. There is a Statute made ſince the King's moſt happy Reſtauration, enumerating Treaſons, which ſays, That all Treaſons ſhall be as in that Act: And further adds, That none ſhall be Convicted of Treaſon, but by two lawful and credible Witneſſes. Now the wiſdom of our Legiſlators, having an Eye to future Safety and paſt Practices, does provide, That no one ſhall ſuffer as a Traytor, but one that is by good and credible teſtimony convicted of Treaſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray ſpeak out, Sir, for I cannot hear you.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I underſtand the meaning applicable to me thus, That ſince the Statute does uſe the word (Credible) as well as Legal, it does judge that both would be very neceſſary. Now that he is not a credible Witneſs I can prove—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why is he not credible? certainly if he be legal he is credible.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: No, my Lord, that does not follow. Firſt the—

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: 'Tis not his time to make this ſort of defence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ſhould have done it before the Witneſs was ſworn, if he would except againſt his Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But why is he not a good Witneſs, pray?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, a man pilloried twice, that hath broke Priſon once, and committed other hainous offences—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is the Record of any of this?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le tell you how I prove it. That worthy Gentleman, Col. Manſel, whom this Villain would have involved in—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt not do thus, abuſe perſons with words without proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He muſt not be ſuffered ſo to do.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I will do ſo no more, indulge a little to my innocency and infirmity.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You don't ſeem to have ſo much infirmity upon you.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Col. Manſel, when this Gentleman was the Kings Evidence, as he is now, brought in the Record of this Gentlemans being pilloried, and the Council did not think fit to commit Col. Manſel, but committed him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you that Record here?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I have not.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: We pray we may go on then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Set up Dr. Oates. Dr. Oates, will you tell what you know of this matter.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he is a Prieſt. I can in ſincerity ſay it. I have heard him ſay Maſs my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, I acknowledge I did it. But my Lord I will ſhew you. Maſs is no proof of a Prieſt: for firſt the Statute makes a diſtinction of Prieſts—

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: He does execute the Office of a Prieſt; for I have been at Confeſſion with him as a Prieſt, and have ſeen him Conſecrate the Sacrament, and I have ſeen his Letters of Orders as a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he wear the Habit of a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, at Maſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, are you ſure you ſaw his Orders as a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ſhew you the Letters of his Orders?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Of what Order is he?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: A Dominican-Fryer he is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay to that?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I can ſay enough; but what can I ſay againſt the King's Evidence? Your Lordſhip ſees this makes a very fine Jingle, but there is no proof of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We can go no further than the Evidence. He ſays, You are a Dominican-Fryer: That he heard you ſay Maſs: That he ſaw you Conſecrate the Sacrament. And I am ſure you allow none but a Prieſt to do that.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I underſtand by the Laws of England, that I am tryed upon a Statute which makes Prieſthood a Crime. Now I will ask Mr. Oates a Queſtion: Mr. Oates, Can you prove, That I received Orders from the See of Rome? You are to prove by this Statute three things againſt me. I am tryed upon a Penal Statute, which ought to be conſtrued moſt in favour of the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Ask him any Queſtions, if you will, but this is not your time for arguing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, we muſt do with you as we have done with others, and will do with the reſt. If you mean that this Statute ſhould never have any Effect, that is, that the Prieſts ſhall not be convicted as ſuch, unleſs we can produce Witneſſes, that ſaw them take Orders, then you have avoided all the Statute; but if ſo be it be plainly proved, That you have done the Acts of a Prieſt, thoſe that none are allow'd of to do, or undertake to do, but a Prieſt, is not this a ſatisfaction, and a plain one too, to your ſelf and all the World, that this Iſſue, whether you are a Prieſt, or not a Prieſt, is well proved in the Affirmative.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw his Letters of Orders.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice, I would ſpeak a little to what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p:
Look you, Sir, you muſt not have ſuch liberty
as this granted to you. You may, if you will, ask Queſtions, but it is not your time to diſpute.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: You muſt not invert the Order of Tryals. When a Witneſs is called, he muſt give his Evidence. If you will ask him any Queſtions you may do it. But if you will obſerve any thing, you have time to do it when the Kings Witneſſes are all heard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: Dr. Oates, the Priſoner did not underſtand ſure what you ſaid. Did not he confeſs to you he had Orders from Rome.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, he did confeſs ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You confeſſed it your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, how comes it to paſs, that I did not come here in a Yellow Coat, and was not arraigned for a Fool? If I am a Prieſt, that I ſhould tell him I was ſuch an one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell, becauſe you did not put it on. If you would ask him any Queſtions, do.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Yes, Whether you do know me to be an Engliſhman? And whether you ſaw me take Orders from the See of Rome?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: You ſaid you were an Engliſhman, and a Gentleman, and the ſon of an Engliſh Gentleman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you deny you are an Engliſhman?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
L. C. J.
sp.p: Me-thinks you ſpeak very like an Engliſhman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: My Lord, we call now Mr. Bedloe. You know the Queſtion, what it is Sir, concerning the Priſoners being a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He is a Prieſt, and an Engliſhman, if his Mother was honeſt, and he honeſtly born; for he is Mr. Anderſons ſon of Oxfordſhire, as I was told.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what ſay you to him, as to his being a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have heard him ſay Maſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever receive the Sacrament from him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Never. But I have ſeen him Adminiſter the Sacrament, and he was in a Prieſts habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I think it was at the Venetian Reſidents; I am ſure it was at ſome of the Embaſſadors Houſes.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: This matter is ſo unlikely, I know not what to ſay to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Upon my Salvation I never ſaw him before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: It is a ſtrange thing, that you ſhould take upon you to ſay upon your Salvation you never ſaw him. How many might come into a Room, and you not ſee them while you are at Maſs?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He might ſee you, tho' you did not ſee him. He might come in, and you not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: Is that any argument, or any thing to the purpoſe, or does that contradict the Evidence? Does the Miniſter, or ought he to know all his Congregation whileſt he is in Preaching?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I never ſaw him, I ſay. My Lord, I'le give you but one Argument, which is called Argumentum Congruentiae.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: To what purpoſe will it be for me to ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: When he was firſt taken I was not ſtirring, but while I was making ready, they told me, There was one ſuſpected to be a Prieſt. I heard him ſpeak in the next Room, and I knew his voice, and ſaid, That is Mr. Anderſon. I preſently knew his tongue before I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You knew him very well then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I never had any great converſe with the man: when he was taken, they asked me, If I knew any thing of this man about the Plot? I told them, No; but he was in Orders from the Church of Rome: for I heard him ſay Maſs at ſuch a place. He told me, ſaid he, I have been in Orders, but I revok'd them, and turned Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Set up Mr. Prance. Pray, Sir, tell what you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I have heard him ſay Maſs ſeveral times at Wild-houſe, and he hath given the Sacrament there, and I have ſeen him take Confeſſions—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then you know him very well?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I never ſaw him in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he hath ſeen you.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice, I will bring Witneſſes to prove, That I never did ſay Maſs at Wild-houſe, nor went to the Chappel: I was an Excommunicated man, for writing for the King's Temporal Power againſt the Pope.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you known him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Seven Years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you ſeen him ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: A dozen times.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: It may ſeem ſtrange that I ſhould have the impudence to deny what this worthy Gentleman ſays. Mr. Prance dare you ſay you know me?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, were you never there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: Well, well, will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Who did I give the Sacrament to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: A whole Rail-full hath been at the Sacrament at a time, ſeveral people I have ſeen receive it from him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he deliver the Sacrament to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: No, he did not, I commonly received at Somerſet-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: We have done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: The Kings Counſel have done with their Evidence, and now you may ſay what you will.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice, may I ſpeak now?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, all the World knows me, and I am known to moſt of the Dignified Clergy in England: My Lord Biſhop of London, and Dr. Lloyd, and the Biſhop of Durham ſent to me to tell me, that if they knew of my Tryal they would be here. My Lord, I have lain under an ill Cenſure for ſcribing and writing againſt the Temporal power of the Church of Rome. I never ſaid Maſs in any Popiſh Church, I am confident, theſe ten Years: that I have ſaid Maſs, I won't deny. I would not tell a lye to ſave my own life, nay, nor would I tell a lye to take away the life of the greateſt Villain upon Earth. But, my Lord, I proteſt there is not one word true that hath been Sworn againſt me, but what Dr. Oates hath ſaid concerning my ſaying Maſs. Oh! my Lord, I would not deny it if I were to be Hang'd preſently, and is not that a great evidence of my innocence and ſincerity. But this does not prove that I am guilty of what I am accuſed for; for I am indicted upon a Penal Statute, and three things muſt be proved ſtrictly to bring me within that Law; Firſt, that I am an Engliſhman—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis proved you are an Oxfordſhire man.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: No, my Father is Lincolnſhire, and my Lord Chief Baron knows him.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Baron.
sp.p: I do know a Gentleman of that name there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedlow.
sp.p: I was told he was Oxfordſhire.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ſpeaks it himſelf to be an Engliſhman. All the World knows it by your Speech.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I know my Father is ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why do you deny it your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: 'Tis one thing to deny it, and another thing to have it proved ſo. I am not to prove it, they are.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays you are ſo.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p:
He talks like a Parrot: theſe things are to be proved ſtrictly; no mans life is to be taken away by preſumption, which is but a Conceit in Law, and ought not to overthrow that Maxim of Law, That Penal Laws ought to be taken moſt ſtrictly in favour of the Priſoner, and I ought to be proved ad literam within the Law, and that according to the Statute made ſince his Majeſties happy Reſtauration, by two lawful Witneſſes, and not only by two lawful, but by two Credible Witneſſes too. And I ſuppoſe the Gentlemen of the Jury being apprized of this my Exception, if they will take this for truth 〈◊〉 theſe men ſay, whom yet perhaps they would not truſt for 〈…〉
• heir Shops, they do as it were wage the Law, and take it upon their Conſciences, that what theſe men ſay is true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So they do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: If theſe things are not well proved, nothing will be proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: Have you any Witneſſes that you would call?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: If you will call any, you may.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: How ſhall I call them, when I did not know of my Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: If you will ſend for any Witneſſes, the Court will ſtay, if they be to any thing material.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I have againſt this Gentleman Mr. Dangerfield almoſt all the Priſoners of the Kings Bench for Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call them, and name them.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Mr. Adderly, Mr. Puller, who can ſay that I never drunk a Pot of Ale with this man while he was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who would you ſend for?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Thoſe perſons, to prove that I had a grudge and prejudice againſt this man, and that I deſired to be removed to Newgate for that very reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: But the Queſtion is, Whether you be a Prieſt, or no? And you can't ſend for any one, that knows you, but will ſay, That he hath taken you for a Prieſt all along.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: But ſtill 'tis but a Preſumption, not a Proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: The Jury is to be Judge of that, how far that goes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you expect for proof? Do you imagine there ſhould be no proof to convict you upon that Statute, unleſs we produce ſome Witneſſes that actually ſaw you take Orders?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Yes, I ſuppoſe ſo, my Lord, becauſe Penal Statutes are to be taken ſtrictly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you then, How vain would you make a Statute of England, the Laws of your Countrey? How idle a thing were it to expect any poſſibility of proof, ſuch as to convict a Prieſt, if this be the interpretation of the Law, That no man ſhould be convicted by a Jury upon this Statute, but one againſt whom two witneſſes ſhould ſwear they ſaw him take Orders? where can we find ſuch a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Admit that this Law were thus evaded, yet there would be no inconvenience, and I will prove it to your Lordſhip by Authority. It was the opinon of all the Judges, delivered about nine years agoe to the King and Council, upon a Queſtion about Laws againſt the Romiſh Recuſants, they all agreed, That this Law was only made in terrorem.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Look you Sir, you muſt not talk ſo, it is not to be permitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Will you go to arraign the Judges here?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, the Kings Counſell did very honeſtly and prudently upon that matter, for ſaid Sir John Keiling, 'tis very true, our Kings have not ſince this Law was made, put the Statute in execution unto Rigor, till you your ſelves occaſioned it: but ſtill the Law was a good Law, and abſolutely neceſſary at its making, as neceſſary as the preſervation of the Queens life, and the quiet of her Dominions; and now 'tis become as neceſſary for the preſervation of the Proteſtant Religion, which all your Arts are employed to undermine; and more neceſſary again, for the preſervation of our Kings life, againſt which your contrivances are ſo bent.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Do you think that you ſhall be heard here to diſpute againſt the Law, and ſay it was no matter for the Law, it is a void Law, and ſcandalize the Judges, that they gave it for their opinion, that it was only in terrorem?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: No, I diſpute for the Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: You muſt employ your time otherwiſe if you intend to be heard,

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Then this is that I require, I deſire theſe things may be proved, Firſt that I am an Engliſhman, and then that I took Orders from Rome, and then that I abode here contrary to the Statute, which things in this penal Statute muſt be proved.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have upon the matter proved the firſt your ſelf in your appeal to my Lord Chief Baron, that he knew your Father, who is a Lincolnſhire man.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: I might be bred and born beyond Sea, tho my Father was ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If you will give no proof to the contrary, a little proof will ſerve the Jurys turn, hearing you ſpeak, and knowing your Father was a Lincolnſhire Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: No Negative can be ſworn, they muſt prove the affirmative.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: That will turn the proof upon you to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: A reaſonable proof againſt you, with ſuch probability, will put it upon you to diſprove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Anderſon, if you have any witneſſes to call for, or ſend for, the Court will give you leave to ſtand by a little and ſend for them; but if you continue to argue in this manner, the Court will give their directions to the Jury.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Mr. Anderſon, the Court will do you all the Juſtice that can be expected. If you have any material witneſſes to be ſent for, the Court will have patience till they come; but then you muſt be ſure they are material witneſſes, for we will not go to looſe time upon a bare ſurmiſe. If it be only to prove this Negative, that Mr. Dangerfield was never in your company in the Kings-Bench, it will ſignify nothing, for there are three witneſſes without him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Have you any witneſſes to prove that you were born beyond Sea, or any thing that is material, we will ſtay for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Ellys.
sp.p: There is nothing now in queſtion, but whether you be an Engliſhman and a Prieſt; and if you can prove that you are not ſo, you ſay well. But I think you deny not now but that you are a Prieſt, only you would have us prove that you are an Engliſhman. Your Speech betrays you, and there is ſo much Evidence againſt you, that I have not heard in any Caſe as I know of. And all your Witneſſes will be to little purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: Only this I deſire to obſerve, That I have been a man always countenanced by the beſt of Kings, and His Privy Council; and if the Parliament had not been diſſolved, I had been protected by the Parliament: Now I ſay, if your Lordſhips think me worthy of any conſideration (as I have been a man that have given ſeveral teſtimonies of my Loyalty, and Obedience to the Government) I deſire your Lordſhips would pleaſe to ſtay till you know the Kings pleaſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You know where you muſt apply your ſelf for that, we are barely upon our Oaths, and ſo is the Jury too, to try the Fact, whether you be a Prieſt; and this I will tell you, and I muſt ſay to you, I dare appeal to your own Conſcience, whether this Iſſue, your being a Romiſh Prieſt, is not as plainly and evidently proved, to the ſatisfaction of all mankind, as any thing can be?

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: But 'tis all by preſumption ſtill.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Well, Gentlemen of the Jury, the matter that he inſiſts upon, are Two things; Firſt, ſays he, You have not proved me to be an Engliſhman, and yet at the ſame time he appeals to ſuch as knew his Father, to be an Engliſh Gentleman; and his Language, his Tongue betrays him. 'Tis true, ſome kind of Evidence is to be given, that he is an Engliſhman, he himſelf tels you, that he is born of Engliſh Parents; but 'tis a forreign
matter, that he ſhould be born beyond Sea. And if it were ſo really, then it comes on his ſide, if he can produce any witneſs he ſays ſomething, otherwiſe we leave it to you, whether you are not ſatisfied in your Conſciences, by hearing him ſpeak, and underſtanding who his Father was, that he is an Engliſhman. The next thing is for his being a Prieſt: I do not know, nor can there be expected a plainer proof than this that hath been given, becauſe he doth thoſe Acts which none but a Prieſt amongſt them does; he ſays Maſs, he Conſecrates the Sacrament, he takes Confeſſion, he gives Abſolution, and all this proved by Four Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Anderſon.
sp.p: That the Clerk does at Maſs, give Abſolution.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does, or can any but a Prieſt Abſolve?

sp.speaker: D. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, the Clerk, he that ſerves at Maſs at that time, gives pro forma Abſolution to the Prieſt, without which, the Prieſt cannot approach to the Altar, after he hath made a general Confeſſion for the whole Congregation, the Clerk abſolves the Prieſt, that he may Abſolve the Congregation.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, the Fact is plain upon you, we muſt never expect to convict a Prieſt upon this Statute, if ſuch proof is not ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: He does acknowledge that Doctor Oates hath heard him ſay Maſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Go on to the next.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: The next we will Try, ſhall be James Corker, with whom the Jury was charged as with the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentleman of the Jury; James Corker, the Priſoner at the Bar, ſtands Indicted for High Treaſon, for that being born within the Kings Dominions, and made a Prieſt by Authority from the See of Rome, did traiterouſly come and abide in England, contrary to the Law. To this he hath pleaded Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Doctor Oates, Mr. Bedloe, and Mr. Praunce, (who were all ſworn) Doctor Oates, pray tell my Lord, and theſe Gentlemen, what you know of this Mr. Corkers being a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he hath ſaid Maſs at Somerſet-Houſe, and before the Proclamation and Declaration in 1674. made againſt the Catholicks, he was one of the Queens Prieſts, he is a Benedictine Monk, and he hath ſaid Maſs at Somerſet-Houſe; and I have heard him ſay Maſs at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In a Prieſts Habit?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſeen him in a Monks Habit.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ever ſeen him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I received the Sacrament from him my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he Conſecrate the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Not that that I received, I cannot ſay whether he did or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do any Adminiſter the Sacrament but Prieſts?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: They are in Orders firſt. And 'tis againſt the Laws of the Church for any but Prieſts to do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: None uſe to do it but Prieſts, doe they?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cann't tell; but he that I took it from, I always took to be a Prieſt: beſides, I ſaw his Patent to be Biſhop of London, and they don't uſe to make them Biſhops before they be Prieſts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ſhew it you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: From whom was that Patent?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats.
sp.p: It was from the See of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: Under what Seal was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cann't tell that, but I remember that I ſaw the Patent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, will you ask him any thing?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When was it that you heard me ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: The firſt time that I heard him ſay Maſs, is near upon Three years agoe, and then I heard him ſay Maſs about the laſt winter was Two years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you heard him ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Several times, a dozen times I believe.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Was there any body with you when you heard me ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I believe there was an whole Church full at Somerſet-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Can you nominate any in particular?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Atkins.
sp.p: How can he do that? He ſays there was an whole Church full.

sp.speaker: M. J. Pemb.
sp.p: Will you ask him any more Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Strode.
sp.p: Then ſet up Mr. Bedloe. Pray Sir, will you tell my Lord and the Jury, what you know of Mr. Corker's being a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have ſeen him wear the Habit of a Benedictine Monk, before the ſuppreſſion of the Covent in the Savoy: and I have ſeen him Confeſſing ſeveral people in Somerſet-Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And gave them Abſolution?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Doe they uſe to let them ſee when they confeſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: They confeſs in publick, but they ſpeak ſo ſoftly we cann't hear, but the whole Chappel ſometimes may be full of people Confeſſing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: About four or five years ſince, when Father Lathum was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever hear him ſay Maſs at Father Lathum's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, I never ſaw him ſay Maſs, but only Confeſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you never ſee him deliver the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When you ſaw me in my Habit, Was it when you came to Father Lathum's?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I Judge ſo it was ſeveral times, with ſeveral of them.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: Can you nominate any one that ſaw me at the ſame time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: There were a whole Chappel full of Catholicks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: That is no great matter whether he can or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Atkins.
sp.p: 'Tis an Immaterial Queſtion, Why do you ask it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: My Lord, What I did, was done ſo privately, that if I went but from Strand-Bridge to the Monks, I either took a Boat and went by Water, or a Coach and went round about to avoid Suſpition.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Then ſet up Mr. Prance. Pray Sir tell what you know of this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I have heard him ſay Maſs at Mr. Pastons in Dukestreet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: Never but once.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: When Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: It may be two years agoe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Atkyns.
sp.p: That is another place too, Mr. Corker.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any thing to Ask him?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What have you then to ſay for your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: My Lord, this I have to ſay for my ſelf, and I do proteſt it to be true, I never in my life did ever ſay Maſs, or hear Confeſſions at Somerſet-houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to Mr. Paston's?

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: No, nor at Mr. Paſton's, nor ever was in the Company of that Man, nor ever ſaw him here in my life to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That may be.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I likewiſe proteſt, that I never ſaid Maſs in any publick place ſince I was borne.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It may be, you count not Mr. Paſton's a publick place.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: If it be a private place, then I ſhould know who were in the Company, and who were admitted there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, you were not 2 or 3 years ago ſo nice, and cautious whom you admitted to ſee you in the Exerciſe of what you call your Religion; becauſe the Execution of the Law was not ſo ſtrict, as now adays it is. And therefore 'tis very probable, and may very well be, that you were at Mr. Paſtons Houſe, and yet not know all the Company.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: But, I ſay, I never did ſay Maſs there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Here are three Witneſſes againſt you, and do you think your bare Word will be taken againſt their three Oaths?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: What ſay you to the Savoy Mr. Corker? and I ask you, becauſe I would know whether you can ſpeak Truth in any thing.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I ſay, as to the Savoy, I never received any one Confeſſion there. And I do proteſt I never ſaid Maſs, nor heard Confeſſion in Somerſet-houſe, nor at Mr. Paston's in Dukes-ſtreet. And, as for the Savoy, I humbly beg, that ſince the denyal of it will not clear me, I may not be my own Accuſer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen of the Jury, you hear what is proved againſt him by three Witneſſes, that they heard him ſay Maſs, and receive Confeſſions, and deliver the Sacrament. They tell you what Order he was of, and that they ſaw him do the Acts of a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: I appeal to all the World that ever came to Somerſet-houſe, Whether ever any one heard me ſay Maſs there?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is one hath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: We will Try William Marſhall next, who was charged upon the Jury as the others.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, William Marſhall, the Priſoner at the Bar, ſtands Indicted for High-Treaſon. The Offence is not for being a Prieſt barely, but that he being born an Engliſhman, within the Kings Dominions, and having received Orders from Rome, did, againſt the Laws of the Kingdom, come and abide here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: Swear Dr. Oates, and Mr. Bedloe (which was done) Dr. Oates, pray ſtand up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay to Mr. Marſhall's being a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have heard him ſay Maſs in the Savoy, and I have ſeen him in that poſture that the Prieſts are in when they give Abſolution.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ſeen him in a Prieſts Habit ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, in his Habit, as a Benedictine Monk.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him give the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, and Conſecrate the Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: Well, Have you any thing to ask him?

sp.speaker: Marſhal.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have known him theſe three years to be a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: That is a year longer then you knew me at the Tryall.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It is a great while ſince that Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, that is a good while ago.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But where Mr. Oates, and when?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: At the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Within the compaſs of three years ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: How does that afford me any occaſion of Defence? I can make no Plea, unleſs he aſcertains time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: 'Tis good Evidence, without confining himſelf to preciſe time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays a Dozen times within that Compaſs.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But why does he not name ſome particular time, for unleſs he name the time, How is it poſſible for us to diſprove him?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you many times in three years.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why within three years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: What if he could tell you when?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis an improper Queſtion that you Ask.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He is not bound to name the day.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Well, I will pitch upon a day now.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Several times laſt Summer was Twelve-Moneth.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: What before the Plot?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
Marſhall.
sp.p: Did you hear me ſay Maſs before you went over to Spain?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood.
sp.p: Mr. Bedloe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Strode.
sp.p: Pray will you tell what you know of Mr. Marſhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I know a great deal of him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What of his being a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I have ſeen him in his Habit, of a Benedictine Monk in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you heard him ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have not: But he hath been preparing to go to take Confeſſions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he own himſelf to be a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He was in the Habit of a Prieſt, but I never ſaw him execute any part of the Office of a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Did you hear him declare, that he hath been going at any time to take Confeſſion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: The Monks have ſaid, when he hath been gone, that he went to take Confeſſions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Have you ever heard him own himſelf to be a Prieſt, or ever ſay, that he was going to take Confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but I have ſeen him in a Monks Habit, and within half an hour he was in a Secular Habit: for when they went abroad they took Confeſſions in their Secular Habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often have you ſeen him in a Monks Habit?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I do not know whether it were more then once. And I Asked then, Where is our Father going?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: And what ſaid they to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: He was going to take Confeſſions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Have not you your ſelf been Confeſſed by Marſhall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to him, will you Ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I do not I think need to Ask this VVitneſs any Queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That ſhall be obſerved for you, if it be to your advantage. If you have any thing to ſay for your ſelf, pray ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: If there be but one Witneſs, VVhat need I make any Defence?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat ſay you to Mr. Oates Teſtimony?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: As for Mr. Oates, if your Lordſhip will but promie, that it ſhall not prejudice me, as to the point of having but one VVitneſs, I have much to ſay for my ſelf: But, I think I need not trouble your Lordſhip with it.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: VVere not you here when Marſhall was Tryed for the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: You muſt not Ask him any Queſtions about that.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſay, if your Lordſhip will but grant, that the VVitneſſes may have free Acceſs, and go away ſafe—

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I believe the Court, upon his Tryal, was ſatisfied that he was in Orders, received from the Church of Rome.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Prance (which was done) What did you hear him ſay at his laſt Tryal?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is hard Evidence truely.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: If he would do it voluntarily of himſelf, he might, we did not Ask him the Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſtood juſt by him when he ſtood at the Bar, and I heard him ſay this to the other Man Mr. Corker, Though we are Priests, this does not reach us.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But is this Good Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: I did hear him ſay, He was a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: VVe did all hear him ſay ſo I believe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Atkyns.
sp.p: I dare ſay none of the Court Asked him the Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I was not Asked, nor had any occaſion, and certainly I ſhould not pick an occaſion to Condemn my ſelf. If I did it, I did it without occaſion. Beſides, my Lord, I humbly conceive, that there muſt be proof againſt a man, or his Confeſſion won't make him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: I would not have you too ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Certainly if a Man do Confeſs at another time, without proof againſt him that will not do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Pemberton.
sp.p: I believe the Jury will take your own Confeſſion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Don't be over Confident of that, for we have Memories too aſwell as you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You are not beli'd by Mr. Prance, I believe, Mr. Marſhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Ellis.
sp.p: If he have confeſs'd it, that is ſure proof enough.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Dugdale. (which was done) You were at the laſt Tryal, Sir, I only ask of you, Can you remember any thing of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dugdale.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance, I heard him own that he was a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Sir John Keiling.
sp.p: Then ſay what you can for your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: My Lord, I have only one material Witneſs againſt me. They ſay that I ſaid ſo; if I did ſay ſo, I muſt ſay it to the Court, and if it was to the Court, it muſt be upon ſome Queſtion asked me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt not ſay ſo; I am afraid if you appeal to the Court, it will do you no good.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: It is plain that you are ſo free of your diſcourſe, that you might ſay things that were not pertinent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis not proper for the Court to give Evidence; if we did, we ſhould do you little Service in this matter.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I do believe I ſhall receive all Juſtice from the Court. And I have experienced it ſo already. Now as to the preſent Teſtimony againſt me, I conceive that only Mr. Oates is a material Witneſs; no one elſe ſwears that they ever ſaw me Officiate or perform the Duty of a Prieſt. As for Mr. Oates, he ſays he heard me ſay Maſs ſeveral times the laſt Summer before the Plot. And Mr. Oates did ſay he was preſent in June, July, and Auguſt. Sir William Waller, though he was pleaſed to forget other things, yet did remember that, and did Teſtifie that he ſaw me in June, July, and Auguſt. Now then I humbly conceive, if he heard me ſay Maſs at any time in that Summer, it muſt be in one of thoſe three Months. Was it in any one of them?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I came over in April from Saint Omers, and I did, as I remember, hear him ſay Maſs one time before I went again, and heard him ſay it ſeveral times after, which was about the middle of June, I think.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Now I ſay, if this Honourable Court will but pleaſe to promiſe, that the Witneſſes that come hither ſhall come and go ſafe, I believe there are Witneſſes that may contradict Dr. Oates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can your Witneſſes prove? you muſt not make bargains with the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Why ſhould you ſuſpect that your Witneſſes ſhould not go free?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Becauſe ſome have received great abuſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: It was ſo ſaid, but not made out.

sp.speaker: M. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: There was only one perſon that came here, and affirmed ſo, but he did not prove it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: And the Court did ſay that they ſhould be puniſhed that did it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: The witneſſes none of them, that I know of, were abuſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: It was only the Kings witneſſes that have been abuſed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can your witneſſes prove.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: He came over the 24th. of April, and I can prove that from the beginning of April to the end of July, I was not within threeſcore Miles of London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: As to his Officiating as a Prieſt, I cannot ſpeak poſitively as to the time, but I think in laſt Summer was twelve Month.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: He ſays, he thinks he did once in that time, but he is ſure, that he did ſee you ſeveral times that Summer.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But what part of the Summer?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: From the time of my coming over again, to the time of the Diſcovery of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it that you heard him firſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: When I heard him firſt was in the year 1677. before I went into Spain: I went away in the Month of April, and I am ſure he ſaid Maſs before I went into Spain; and when I came back again in the Winter, I came in November, and ſtay'd in Town about ten days, and then went to the Savoy and heard him ſay Maſs.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: What November?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Before the Summer I came out of Flanders.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays he went into Spain in April, (77.)

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: And he heard me ſay Maſs before he went over?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Pray look, my Lord, Mr. Oates will confeſs himſelf, he was but newly reconcil'd to the Church of Rome a little while before he went.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I was reconcil'd to the Church on Aſh-wedneſday, and I went in April following.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Where did you hear me ſay Maſs then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In the Savoy, at that time before I went into Spain.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Do you pretend to have known the Savoy ever before your coming back again?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He does Swear it.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: So he does, but he can't prove it. Mr. Oates came over in the Company, as he ſays, of Mr. Thimbleby and Mr. Hitchcock, and by his means he did get to be commended to be received into the Order of the Benedictines, and he was then ſent to Mr. Pickering in order to it; Now, my Lord, is it credible that Mr. Oates having no acquaintance with the Savoy before he had acquaintance with Mr. Hitchock, which was when he came from Spain, ſhould hear me ſay Maſs before he went thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: All this is but a Story to the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What a wild inference do you make from this un-intelligible buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Mr. Oates ſays ſo himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: We all know you ſaid Maſs ſo openly in the Savoy, that any People whatſoever might come, and you did not know who they were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Though he was not one of your Order, yet he might know you.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: To my knowledge there was never three Maſſes ſaid in the World at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: The World knows the contrary.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Let Mr. Oates be poſitive in any thing, and we will diſprove him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: He hath gone as near it as is neceſſary; he tells you, after his Reconciliation, before he went over into Spain.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: But I ſay, he could not be at the Savoy before he was acquainted there, and I can bring Witneſſes to prove, that I was not then at the Savoy; but I pray, my Lord, will theſe Witneſſes do me any good?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What will they prove?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: That all the Summer, from the beginning of April to the end of the Summer, I was in the Countrey, threeſcore Miles from London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I am not ſo poſitive in that, my Lord, but as near as I remember, before I went into Spain again. Your Lordſhips all know that I was not ſo poſitive as to any one time; but the Summer before the Plot broke out, I heard him ſay Maſs ſeveral times in the Summer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now he is poſitive that he ſaw you ſay Maſs in the Summer before the Plot was diſcovered. The ſubſtance of his Depoſition was your ſaying Maſs, the time is not material: he tells of a many times within that compaſs.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: How ſhall I diſprove that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: He hath given you one particular time from Aſhwedneſday, when he was reconciled to Rome, till he went to Spain in April.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: If he names times, then am I able to diſprove him: and he did name one, but when he ſaw me offer to prove by Witneſſes, That I was not then in Town, he goes off from it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible for Witneſſes to be poſitive to a day, a week, or ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Ellis.
sp.p: How is it poſſible to be ſo, unleſs it be a thing that he had taken ſuch particular notice of, as to intend to Swear to it, and give Evidence about it afterwards. Now, I believe, Dr. Oates at that time had no thoughts of giving Evidence as to any ſuch matter; but this he is poſitive in, That he did hear you ſay Maſs at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: My Lord, if Mr. Oates had ſaid he had ſeen me Officiate at Somerſet-houſe, or Wild-houſe, it might have been ſomething like; but at the Savoy, it is known, That none are let in but Friends, nor could Mr. Oates come in, but upon a particular acquaintance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How does that appear ſo?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: By thoſe that live in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: You muſt not ſpend the Courts time in this manner of diſcourſe. If you have any Witneſſes that you think in your ſelf are material, the Court will ſuffer you to call them, and pray call them preſently.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Here is the Houſe-keeper her ſelf that will witneſs, That ſhe never ſaw Mr. Oates there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If the great Turk had come there with apair of Beads and a Crucifix, you would have let him come in. But in the mean time, Mr. Oates, you have given him a pretty compaſs of time, whereby he hath an opportunity of diſproving of what you ſay. And you give him one particular ſhort time, but can you give any time afterwards in the Summer you ſpeak of, within any Month, or two, or three. Becauſe you ſay at ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot be poſitive, but I will tell you one time was the Sunday before they held their Conſpiracy, which was, I verily believe, the Sunday before the 21th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you believe it was in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I do, and confine my ſelf to the Month of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Then call Ellen Rigby.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I was acquainted with Mr. Pickering ſoon after my being reconciled, and being acquainted with him, I went along with him ſeveral times to the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: What do you talk of one Hitchcock, and I know not whom, he was acquainted with Pickering before.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: VVhen, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Preſently after he was reconciled.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: VVell, but you pretend now, that ſince you came over here, you were in the Savoy; Had you a Key to get in?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He was reconciled on Aſhwedneſday, he went in April to Spain.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Here is Ellen Rigby.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVell, what would you have with her?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I ask, Did ſhe ever ſee Mr. Oates in the Summer before laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Don't you lead your VVitneſs with ſuch Queſtions.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I have ſeen him when I ſee him come to ask Charity of Mr. Pickering.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Twice or Thrice.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat time in the Summer?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I cannot ſay, but I ſaw him in Summer was Twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Why then did not this Woman, when ſhe knew this Evidence that would lay a blemiſh upon me, come and give it for Pickering to have ſaved him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to ask this Woman this Queſtion. Whether ſhe ever heard you ſay Maſs?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, with all my heart; and if ſhe ſays ſhe hath, I will be hang'd without any more ado.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Then you are ſure your Proſelytes will ſay any thing you would have them?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I my ſelf am a perfect ſtranger to the Savoy in a manner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Is he not acquainted with the Savoy?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Yes, he was there one Month, when Pickering was taken.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Pray ask her whether ever, before Mr. Oates went over, ſhe ſaw him in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſhall have your Queſtion asked, but do you think you can build upon that, if ſhe did not ſee him, he did not ſee you. Did you ever ſee Dr. Oates there betwixt March and April, before he went over into Spain?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: No, there was no body in the houſe but Mr. Pickering.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there never Maſs ſaid in the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Yes, while her Majeſties Servants were in the houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But was there Maſs never ſaid ſince in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Never ſince I came out of it, which was a Twelve-month ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was there not Maſs ſaid in three or four years time there?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: Not in our houſe, I lived but in one houſe.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I call her to know whether Dr. Oates was there? And my Lord, here is that which I inſiſt upon, That none is let in there to hear Maſs, but thoſe that have ſome particular acquaintance and intimacy in the houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: She only ſpeaks to one particular part of the houſe. She can't ſay but Maſs was ſaid in the other parts.

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: There was no Maſs ſaid there, that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, was there no Maſs ſaid, but in that particular houſe you lived in?

sp.speaker: Rigby.
sp.p: I can't ſay that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But the Queſtion is, whether ever you, Mr. Oates, ſaw him ſay Maſs in this womans houſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not know that ever I ſaw this woman in all my life, before the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: He came there under a diſguiſed name.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you he went along with Pickering.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Pickering ſerved the Maſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call your Witneſſes, if you have any other.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I can prove that I was out of Town the whole Summer, from the beginning of April to the end of the Summer. But if Mr. Oates will not ſtand to any time, I cannot be able to diſprove him. But then Ile only offer one or two things more.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you come to London, in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: I will tell you as near as I can to a day. I came in the middle of Bartholomew Fair, which begins the 24th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So it was the latter end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, if you have any Witneſſes, call them, and do not ſpend the Courts time in vain.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p:
My Lord, I have ſomething very material, I think, to offer. The only material Witneſs that is now againſt me, was a Witneſs againſt me in my laſt Tryal; now I do conceive that I being found, Not Guilty at the laſt Tryal, that Witneſs ought to be look'd
upon as Perjured. And I appeal to the Court, whether it were ſo or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Atkins.
sp.p: That's a falſe Collection, Mr. Marſhall.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange inference you make, Do you think, that every Witneſs is Perjured, becauſe the Jury don't find according to what he ſays? He is not Perjured, for he may Swear true, and the Jury not believe him.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
